message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is sickle cell disease, which is autosomal recessive and results in the production of abnormal hemoglobin that causes vaso-occlusion. Target cells are seen in blood smears, and Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in these patients. However, an individual only needs one defective β-globin gene to have the sickle cell trait, not two.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is sickle cell anemia, which is an autosomal recessive condition that causes valine instead of glutamine in the β-globin gene. Complications of sickle cell anemia are due to vaso-occlusion, target cells are seen in blood smear, and Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in these patients. However, the statement that an individual needs 2 defective β-globin genes to have the sickle cell trait is false - an individual needs only 1 defective β-globin gene to have the sickle cell trait, while 2 defective genes are required to have the full-blown sickle cell disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Sickle cell anemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, and an individual needs 2 defective β-globin genes to have the disease. The other statements are true - complications are due to vaso-occlusion, target cells are seen in blood smear, and Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in these patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is sickle cell anemia, which is an autosomal recessive condition. Complications are due to vaso-occlusion and target cells are seen on blood smear. However, an individual only needs one defective β-globin gene to have the sickle cell trait. Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia, so statement D is true. Therefore, the false statement is C.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the condition is autosomal-recessive, an individual needs 2 defective β-globin genes to have the sickle cell trait is false. The other statements are true: complications are due to vaso-occlusion, target cells are seen in blood smear, and Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in these patients. The crew cut appearance of the skull is due to increased erythropoiesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is sickle cell disease, which is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene that results in a valine substitution for glutamine. Complications of sickle cell disease are due to vaso-occlusion and ischemia. Target cells are seen in blood smear. An individual needs 2 defective β-globin genes to have sickle cell disease, while having one gene results in the sickle cell trait. Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease. Thus, statement (C) is false.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is sickle cell anemia, which is not autosomal-recessive but rather is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene. Option C is false as an individual needs to have 2 defective β-globin genes to have the disease, not the trait. The other options are true for sickle cell anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described in the question is sickle cell anemia, which is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the production of abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes red blood cells to become rigid and change shape, leading to vaso-occlusion and tissue damage. Complications are due to vaso-occlusion (A) and target cells (cells with a bull's-eye appearance) are seen in the blood smear (B). However, sickle cell trait is caused by having one normal hemoglobin gene and one HbS gene, not two defective β-globin genes (C). Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in sickle cell patients (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The condition described is sickle cell disease, which is an autosomal-recessive condition that produces valine instead of glutamine in the β-globin gene. Complications in sickle cell disease are due to vaso-occlusion. Target cells are seen in blood smear in sickle cell disease. An individual needs to have two defective β-globin genes to have the disease, not necessarily the trait (which is caused by having one defective gene and one normal gene). Salmonella paratyphi can cause osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease. Therefore, the false statement is (C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely diagnosed with sickle cell anemia, which is an autosomal-recessive condition that produces abnormal β-globin chains. Complications in sickle cell anemia are due to vaso-occlusion, and target cells are seen in blood smear. However, an individual needs 2 defective β-globin genes to have sickle cell anemia, not the sickle cell trait. Salmonella paratyphi is known to cause osteomyelitis in sickle cell patients. Therefore, statement (C) is false.
